titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Mont Pèlerin Society records
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Olga Verhovskoy Dunlop and Rachel Yamada

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-07-03T08:58-0700

change.item: Revised to add links to digital collections site by Sarah Patton.

physdesc.extent: 164 manuscript boxes, 1 oversize box, 1 card file box, 10 envelopes

did.abstract: Correspondence, conference papers, programs, meeting materials, schedules, minutes, financial and membership records, essays, printed matter, sound recordings, and photographs relating to economic policy, laissez-faire, and liberty. Digital copies of select records also available at https://digitalcollections.hoover.org.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Use copies of all sound recordings in this collection are available for immediate access; digital copies also available at https://digitalcollections.hoover.org. To view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Mont Pèlerin Society records, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1981, with increments received in subsequent years.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

altformavail.head: Alternate Forms Available
altformavail.p: Digital copies of select records also available at https://digitalcollections.hoover.org.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The first installment of the Mont Pèlerin Society records held at the Hoover Institution Archives was received in 1981 and described in a preliminary inventory that is now superseded by the present register.

Those initial records consisted mainly of Albert Hunold's correspondence, which now constitutes the bulk of the Correspondence series, and of his files relating to the general and regional meetings he organized as secretary of the society from 1948 to 1960, which are to be found in the Meetings File series and which also includes material relating to subsequent meetings up to 1990. It should be noted that the correspondence for the first meeting in 1947 also contains important letters dating back to 1945 regarding the founding of the Society.

The remainder of Albert Hunold's papers received in 1981 can be found in the Office File series, particularly the circulars and minutes of meetings. Also included are issues of The Mont Pèlerin Quarterly, edited by Hunold, and his 1962 writing "How the Mont Pèlerin Society Lost Its Soul," which gives his perspective on the so-called "Hunold Affair."

Later, in 1987, the Hoover Archives received the papers of several treasurers of the society, which can be found in the Treasurers' File series. Here too, the correspondence of these officers is particularly noteworthy, as is the correspondence with foundations, especially the Relm Foundation, regarding travel and other grants for members of the Society. Financial records and other materials relating to the meetings, however, were added to the Meetings File series.
The records in the smaller Newsletter File series, received in 1995, are also interesting, especially for the correspondence of Eric Brodin, one of the editors of The Mont Pèlerin Society Newsletter.
Finally, the collection includes a large amount of photographs, film strips, and sound tape reels, mostly relating to the Society's meetings.

Researchers interested in the activities of the society should also consult the Friedrich A. von Hayek papers at the Hoover Archives, particularly its series on the Mont Pèlerin Society in boxes 71-89, as well as the papers of several other prominent members such as John Davenport, Milton Friedman, Gottfried Haberler, F. A. Harper, Fritz Machlup, G. Warren Nutter, Karl Popper, and Gordon Tullock.
Also available for consultation in the reading room of the Hoover Archives is the excellent book by R. M. Hartwell, A History of the Mont Pèlerin Society (1995).

Additional records of the Mont Pèlerin Society were received by the archives in 2011 from Edwin J. Feulner, the treasurer of the Mont Pèlerin Society. The 2011 Incremental Materials series covers aspects of the Society's activities from 1974 to 2001, particularly meetings, membership, fellowships and awards. The papers are in roughly chronological order.

The 2013 Incremental Materials series covers the activities of the Mont Pèlerin Society from 1976 to 2012 and include institutional financial records, meetings, conference materials, membership information, the F. A. Hayek Essay Competition materials, various newsletters, and institutional correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Booklets; circulars; minutes; printed matter, including writings by members of the society and issues of The Mont Pèlerin Quarterly (edited by Albert Hunold); programs of meetings; a subject file; and writings by Albert Hunold. Arranged alphabetically by physical form.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Material related to general, regional, and directors' meetings organized by the society, including agendas, correspondence, lists of participants, memoranda, papers presented, programs, and miscellany related to the organization of the meetings. Arranged chronologically by date of meeting and alphabetically by physical form thereunder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence of Albert Hunold with Friedrich A. von Hayek, Wilhelm Röpke, William E. Rappard, Walter Eucken, F. Schnabel, Alexander Rüstow, and several other members. Also includes regrets and thank-you letters from participants.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes Wilhelm Röpke and Alexander Rüstow, "A Note on the Urgent Necessity of Re-Orientation of Social Science," Colloque Walter Lippmann, Institut International de Coopération Intellectuelle, Paris, France, August 1938; Albert Hunold, K. Brunner, and C. Mötteli, "Zur Frage der Gründung einer sozialwissenschaftlichen Studiengemeinschaft," Zurich, Switzerland, 8 December 1943; Friedrich A. von Hayek, "Historians and the Future of Europe," Cambridge, England, 28 February 1944; Wilhelm Röpke and Hans Zbinden, "Projekt einer internationalen Monatsschrift, Geneva and Bern, April 1945; Wilhelm Röpke, "Plan for an International Periodical," Geneva, Switzerland, August 1945. Also includes an undated manuscript by Wilhelm Röpke, "Some Notes on the German Problem," Geneva, Switzerland.

did.unittitle: Mont Pèlerin Society meeting at Berlin, Germany,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Part 1

Unidentified German speaker speaking in English on permanent inflation; the chairman, Hunold covering administrative issues; Professor Baudin speaking in French without translation; and Müller-Armack responding to permanent inflation and the policies of the German government.
Part 2
Description is currently unavailable.
Part 3
Description is currently unavailable.
Part 4
Description is currently unavailable.
Part 5

Unidentified French speaker; a woman speaking on the Cuban situation towards communism; an unidentified German speaker, and following English translation, on outlawing political parties; an unidentified English speaker on outlawing political parties; an unidentified German speaker, and following English translation, on implications of the industrial revolution; an unidentified English speaker on the difference between the Socialist and Communist parties in America; an unidentified speaker with a Mexican accent; an unidentified English speaker on the previous day’s issues; and an unidentified English speaker on Communism in Sweden.
Part 6

The majority is a discussion chaired by Ludwig von Mises about the welfare state. There are many speakers, most unidentified, including Mises and F. A. Hayek. Before this session on the tape, Mises talks on the uselessness of outlawing communist parties in fighting communism.
Part 7
Description is currently unavailable.
Part 8
Description is currently unavailable.
Part 9

For the majority of this recording, Hayek discusses traditional liberalism. He identifies its past and how it relates to contemporary thought and trends. The overreaching theme of his talk, as he mentions at the beginning, is to analyze these things so that liberals can present their views without referring to the classical champions of the philosophy and increase the popularity of liberalism.
Part 10
Hayek excerpt, unidentified German speaker, discussion of administrative issues.

dao.title: Mont Pèlerin Society meeting at Berlin, Germany

did.unittitle: Mont Pèlerin Society meeting at Princeton, New Jersey,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Part 1

1958 September 8, P.M. session. Opening greeting by Professor F. A. Hayek and Princeton Professor Gardner Patterson. Addresses by Ludwig von Mises, "Liberty and Property," Pierre Goodrich, Felix Morley, "Meaning of Freedom."
Part 2
1958 September 9, A.M. session. Discussions on the welfare state, following papers by W. Hagenbuch (Cambridge, England) and W. Röpke (Geneva).
F. A. Hayek concentrates on compulsory insurance and the government as provider as compared to private providers.
Mr. Andrews also speaks on healthcare.

Ludwig von Mises speaks about the political consequences of the welfare state. He begins by recounting the origin and semantics of the term "welfare state." He then concentrates on how the interests of individual members of a legislature is not the welfare of the nation, but the welfare of its constituents. He believes the system of interventionist government leads to inflation being the only way out.
Jasper Crane compares the welfare state to cancer. Professor Hutt continues this analogy and also offers tactics on how to argue against the welfare state.
Part 3

1958 September 9, P.M. session. More discussions on the welfare state. The speakers are Felix Morley, including his analysis of James Madison; L. Baudin; Salvadori, who defines liberty as an economic system currently called capitalism and argues capitalism is a child of security; and Pfister.
Part 4
1958 September 10, A.M. session. Professor Milton Friedman, Mr. Sheffield, Professor F. A. Hayek, W. H. Hutt, and Henry Hazlitt.
Part 5

1958 September 10, noon session. Various speakers give their thoughts on inflation and monetary policy. The speakers are Eugenio Gudin (Brazil); Dr. Romulo Ferrero (Lima, Peru); Leonard E. Read (New York, U.S.A.); and Jacques Rueff (Paris-Luxembourg – English translation).
Part 6

1958 September 10, P.M. session. Volkmar Muthesius (Frankfurt, Germany – English translation), Milton Friedman (Chicago, Illinois, U.S.A.), C. Iversen (Copenhagen, Denmark), and Graham Hutton (London, England).
Part 7

1958 September 11, A.M. session. This session concerns labor unions, their influence on inflation, employee choice, labor history of the 20th century, and other related matters. The featured speakers are T. Wilson (Oxford, England), S. Petro (New York, U.S.A.), Goetz Brifs (Washington, D.C., U.S.A.), Jacques Rueff (Paris, France – English translation), S. W. Alexander (London, England), and Ludwig von Mises.
Part 8
Likely a continuation of the 1958 September 11, A.M. session. Speakers include Ludwig von Mises and Crawford H. Greenwalt, Pres of E. I. DuPont de Nemours Company.
Part 9

1958 September 11, P.M. session. This session focuses on agricultural economics. The speakers are W. H. Hutt (Capetown, South Africa), James C. Ingebretsen (California, U.S.A.), W. Hagenbuch (England), E. Bieri (Zurich, Switzerland), G. Briefs (U.S.A.), T. Wilson (England), S. Petro (U.S.A.), and L. Baudin (Paris, France – English translation).
Part 10
1958 September 12, A.M. session. W. M. Curtis (U.S.A.), Antony G. A. Fisher (England), H. Nichaus (Bonn, Germany), E. Gudin (Brazil), and Bruno Leoni (Italy).
Part 11

1958 September 12, P.M. session. This session focus on agricultural economics. The speakers are R. Ferrero (Peru), S. H. Frankel (Oxford, England), Jay Morrison (Seattle, Washington, U.S.A.), Felix Morley (Baltimore, Maryland, U.S.A.), L. Baudin (Paris, France – English translation), Harry D. Gideonese (Brooklyn, New York, U.S.A.) (on Russian visit), and Max Thurn (U.S.A.).
Part 12
1958 September 13, A.M. session. John Davenport (U.S.A.), D. McCord Wright (Montreal, Canada), Gustave Velasco (Mexico), and Nobutane Kinehi (Tokyo, Japan).
Part 13

1958 September 13, A.M. session. Frankel on escaping "the tyranny of the community," property rights, conditions that promote good government, and how to improve living conditions in Africa. Ludwig von Mises on positivity vs. negativity and central planning vs. individuals’ planning. Gudin on the roots of government intervention. Ferrero on the development of underdeveloped countries. John Davenport ponders defense issues. Hayek brings the conference to a close.
Part 14

A second copy of 1958 September 11, P.M. session, with possible additional content. Ludwig von Mises, cont’d. S. W. Alexander (London), W. H. Hutt (Capetown, South Africa), James C. Ingebretsen (California, U.S.A.), W. Hagenbuch (England), E. Bieri (Zurich, Switzlerland), G. Briefs (U.S.A.), T. Wilson (England), S. Petro (U.S.A.), and L. Baudin (Paris, France – English translation).

dao.title: Mont Pèlerin Society meeting at Princeton, New Jersey

did.unittitle: Mont Pèlerin Society meeting at Oxford,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Part 1

Hayek (as Chairman) covers introductory and administrative issues. Briefs presents a paper entitled "Some Economic Aspects of the Pluralistic Society," which includes discussion of liberalism, freedom, and labor unions among other topics. Brozen and Frankel critique the paper with response by Briefs to Brozen.
Part 2
Frankel (continued), Hayek, Villey, Bauer, Briefs, Hayek (organizational remarks)
Part 3
Concerns monopolies. Professor Jewkes (Chairman), Professor Machlup, Professor Dennison
Part 4
Professor Dennison (continued), Professor Jewkes (time until coffee-break)
Part 5

Concerns monopolies. Professor Jewkes (Chairman), Professor Müller-Armack (Deutsch), Uebersetzung Grosse-Schware, Professor Müller-Armack (Deutsch), Uebersetzung Grosse-Schware, Professor Müller-Armack (Deutsch), Uebersetzung Grosse-Schware, George Schwartz, Henry Hazlitt, Griffin, Professor Dennison, Professor Machlup
Part 6
Professor Dennison (Chairman), Professor Leoni, Professor Shenfield, Mr. Kemp, Mr. Kelf-Cohen, Mr. Hazlitt, Professor Shenfiedl, McCord Right, Mr. Andrews, Professor Jewkes (remarks on the agenda)
Part 7

Concerns full employment policy. Hazlitt (Chairman), Pfister (Deutsch), Uebersetzung Grosse-Schware, Pfister (Deutsch), Uebersetzung Grosse-Schware, Pfister (Deutsch), Uebersetzung Grosse-Schware, Pfister (Deutsch), Uebersetzung Grosse-Schware, Hazlitt, Alchian, Hazlitt, Petro, Hahn
Part 8

Concerns full employment policy. Hahn (continued), Nyardi, Muthesius (Deutsch) viel zu leise, Uebersetzung Grosse-Schware, Muthesius (Deutsch) viel zu leise, Uebersetzung Grosse-Schware, Fertig – viel zu leise, Brozen, Harland Shaw, Alchian, Pfister, Frankel, Dr. Hunold (Angaben zur Tageseinteilung)
Part 9
Concerns imperfect freedom. Professor Frankel (Chairman), Henry Luce offers a critique of classical liberalism, Professor Hayek, Madariaga, Oliver Smedley, Professor Ropke
Part 10
Professor Ropke (continued), Jacques Rueff, Professor Frankel, MacCord Wright, Professor Frankel (Danksagung)
Part 11
Concerns agriculture. P. T. Bauer (chairman), Professor Brandt, Antony Fisher, Professor Nash, Professor Petersen, Professor Morrison, Professor Rostow, answer by Professor Brandt, P. T. Bauer
Part 12

Concerns Russia’s economic achievements. Professor Shenfield, Professor Nutter, W. Forster (Deutsch), Uebersetzung Grosse-Schware, Forster (Deutsch), Uebersetzung Grosse-Schware, American speaker (Hazlitt?), American speaker, Dr. Sennholz, Professor Allais
Part 13

Concerns Russia’s economic achievements (continued). Shenoy, P. T. Bauer, Karl Brandt, Goetz Briefs, Thurn, Dr. Petersen, MacCord Wright, Kelf-Cohen, Shenoy, A. Shenfield (Bemerkungen zum Tagesablauf)
Part 14
Concerns strategies and tactics. F.A. Hayek (introductory remarks), Harris, Seldon, Buchanan, Davenport, Velasco, Diana Spearman, Hayek (Zwischenbemerkung)
Part 15
L’Economie Francaise Apres L’Assainissement Financier. Speakers: Rueff (in French), Uebersetzung (English), Morley, Heilperin, Hornbostel, Hahn, Rueff, Morley
Part 16

L’Economie Francaise Apres L’Assainissement Financier (continued). Speakers: Professor Morley (Chairman), Jacques Rueff (majority of the tape), Professor Heilperin, Professor Hornbostel, Professor Hahn
Part 17

Concerns strategy and tactics. Professor Hayek (Chairman), Professor Van Sickle, P. T. Bauer, Dr. Hunold, Professor Brozen, Professor Kemp, O. Smedley, Professor Jewkes, Mr. Koether, Mr. Alexander, Professor Dietze, Davenport (Schlussworte), Professor Hayek (Bemerkungen zun Tagesablauf)
Part 18

Concerns education. Introductory remarks by John Davenport, Professor Morley*, Davenport, Professor Van Sickle, Professor Right (?), Professor Nutter, Davenport (Zwischenbemerkung), Professor Jewkes, Davenport (Zwischenbemerkung), Shaw, Dr. Hunold, Davenport (Zwischenbemerkung), Frankel, Davenport (Zwischenbemerkung)
* bei 261 durch unsachgemass Behandlung des Bandes seitens Dr. V. Ilosvay nicht mehr abzuhoren. Herausnahme des Bandes soll in Gegenwart von Dr. Hunold erfolgt sein. Storung festgestellt: 4.1.60.
Part 19

Concerns insurance and health. Davenport, Dr. Campbell, Mrs. Campbell, geloscht durch falsche Behandlung seitens Dr. V. Ilosvay, festgestellt 4.1.1960, Davenport und Zwischenruf, nicht zu verstehen (Professor Jewkes, George Schwartz?), brit. Spreecher (Mr. Smedley), amerik. Spreecher (Professor Bunchanan?), Mrs. Widener, amerik. Spreecher, amerik. Spreecher (Mr. Hazlitt), amerik. Spreecher, Davenport, Schlusswort Professor Hayek

dao.title: Mont Pèlerin Society meeting at Oxford

did.unittitle: Mont Pèlerin Society meeting at Kassel, Germany,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Part 1
6 September 1960 – 9:30-11:00. Chairman opens the conference. German economic minister Erhard on freedom and order, Rustow on freedom and communism.
Part 2

Sprecherangaben zu den einzelnen Tonbändern, Wilhelmshöhe 1960. Band Dienstag, 6 September – 11:30-13:00. Uhr. Hunold (organisat. Bemerkhung), Böhm (Chairman), Röpke, Böhm, Leoni, Böhm (organisat. Bemerkhung), Hunold (organisat. Bemerkhung)
Part 3

Sprecherangaben zu den einzelnen Tonbändern, Wilhelmshöhe 1960. Band Dienstag, 6 September – 17:00-19:00. Uhr. L. von Mises (Chairman), Shaw, Heilperin, Veit, McCord Wright, von Mises, Briefs, Kuehnelt-Leddihn, Hahn, Veit, Shaw, Leoni, Röpke, Erhard (Deutsch), Erhard (translations Grosse Schware), von Mises, Hunold (organisat.Bemerkung)
Part 4

Public opinion in a free society. Sprecherangaben zu den einzelnen Tonbändern. Band Mittwoch, 7 September 1960 – 9.30-11:00. Uhr. Dr. Hunold (Chairman), Fertig (nicht zu schreiben, da paper verlesen wird), Wesemann, Dr. Hunold, Hoof, Dr. Hunold (organisat. Bemerkung)
Part 5

Sprecherangaben zu den einzelnen Tonbändern. Band Mittwoch, 7 September 1960 – 11:30-13:00. Uhr. Haberler (Chairman), Dr. Hunold (organis. Bemerkung), Haberler, Schmölders, Haberler, Kuehnelt-Leddihn, D. McCord Wright, Reig, Haberler
Part 6

Public opinion in a free society. 7 September 1960 – 17:00-19:00. Prof. Navarro and the linguistics of defending liberalism, the reporter (in French), Ludwig Von Mises on consumers and advertisers, Milton Friedman on the preservation of freedom and the actions of people, question to Professor Friedman, Professor Feaster (sp?) (in German), an unidentified speaker with a German accent, unidentified speaker on inflation and prices, unidentified speaker from the morning session.
Part 7
Sprecherangaben zu den einzelnen Tonbändern, Wilhelmshöhe 1960. Band Donnerstag, 8 September – 9:30-10:45 Uhr.
Continued from 7 September: Heilperin, Veit (?), V.Kuehnelt-Leddihn, Chairman Loveday

8 September: Villey (Chairman), Forster (deutsch), Villey (Zwischenbemerkung), Hunold (Zwischenbemerkung Organisation), Van Sickle (liest sein paper), Duncan, Villey (Zwischenbemerkung), Rougier (nur Anfang)
Part 8

Sprecherangaben zu den einzelnen Tonbändern, Wilhelmshöhe 1960. Band Donnerstag, 8 September – 10:45-12:30. Uhr. Rougier (Fortsetzung), Villey, Renooij, Villey (Zwischenbemerkungen), translation of Forster (Grosse-Schware), Hunold, Friedman, Röpke, Rustow (deutsch), translation of Rustow, Thurn, Pfister (deutsch), translation of Pfister (Grosse-Schware), v. Kuehnelt-Leddihn, Fredborg, Heilperin, Rustow, translation of Rustow (Grosse-Schware), Stigler, Navarro, Davenport, v. Kuehnelt-Leddihn, Shaw, Zuloaga. All speeches typed.
Part 9

8-9 September 1960. The tape begins with an overlap of the end of tape 30, with Navarro as the first speaker heard on tape 31. The rest of this tape (9 September 1960 – 9:30-10:50) concerns economic and financial problems of the West. Leoni serves as chairman. Papers include "Gold Revaluation and Dollar Devaluation" by Albert Hahn of Paris, "Stabilization and the Collective Bargaining Ideal" by Professor Clarence Philbrook of Chapel Hill, and "A New Stage in International Monetary Policy" by Veit from Frankfurt.
Part 10

Sprecherangaben zu den einzelnen Tonbändern, Wilhelmshöhe 1960. Band Freitag, 9 September – 11:30-13:00. Uhr. Veit (Schluss), Leoni, Haberler (?), coffee break, Dr. Hunold, Chairman (Amerikaner), Loveday (reads his paper), Grantchester, Heilperin, Winterberger, Schwartz, Haberler, Rogge, Thurn, Spat (Anfang)
Part 11
9 September 1960 – 17:30-19:00, 21:00-21:40. Includes overlap with part 8. In the additional program, Professor Hayek serves as chairman. The session concerns administrative issues of the society.
Part 12
10 September 1960 – 09:30-11:00. Discussing Galbraith’s book. Panelists: Stigler, Hayek, Davenport. Other members respond to the panelists’ ideas.
Part 13

Sprecherangaben zu den einzelnen Tonbändern, Wilhelmshöhe 1960. Band Samstag, 10 September – 11:30-13:00. Uhr. Hoff, Röpke, Hoff, Heilperin, von Mises on nationalization and socialism, Haberler, Villey, Haberler, Hunold, Villey, Röpke, Schmölders (deutsch), Röpke, Villey (deutsch), Villey (franz.), von Mises, Heilperin, (Deutscher, spricht englisch), Hoff, Röpke (Schlusswort). The common market is also a subject of the talks.
Part 14

Sprecherangaben zu den einzelnen Tonbändern der Tagung Wilhelmshöhe 1960. Band "Generalversammlung." Speakers are Hayek, Philbrook, Zwischenbemerkung, Zwischenrufe, Davenport, and Hoff. It is the 10th official, general meeting of the Mont Pelerin Society. It concerns the finances and leadership of the society.

dao.title: Mont Pèlerin Society meeting at Kassel, Germany

did.unittitle: Felix Morley speech, "Europe after Suez: An American Viewpoint,"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Morley speaks about federalism in America, imperialism, and a federated Europe as seen through an outline of American history. Vorlesung 25.

dao.title: Felix Morley speech, "Europe after Suez: An American Viewpoint"

dao.title: "Auxilio economico: Ruta hacia la libertad o la esclavitud"

did.unittitle: Albert Hunold on the Dr. Nyaradi WLS radio program,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fresh from a trip through the continent, Dr. Hunold describes conditions in Africa. He believes there is widespread discontent, with South Africa being an exception. Nyaradi asks him about Chinese and Soviet influence on the continent. He also comments on the influence of the British and Dutch.

dao.title: Albert Hunold on the Dr. Nyaradi WLS radio program

did.unittitle: Albert Hunold on the Dr. Nyaradi WLS radio program,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nyaradi interviews Hunold about Switzerland, other European countries, and European integration.

dao.title: Albert Hunold on the Dr. Nyaradi WLS radio program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A well produced program, likely about Röpke. In German.

11 postcards depicting the area around Kassel, Germany, where the 1960 meeting was held

2 prints, one depicting Peter Stanlis, and one depicting Robert E. Hall and Alvin Rabushka,
